title: Pushing the Limits of Electron Ptychography with Physics-informed Bayesian Optimization
content: The rapid development of detector hardware and reconstruction techniques allowed electron ptychography (EP) to achieve unprecedent spatial and depth resolutions that far exceed the theoretical resolution limits of focusing optics [1-3]. To date, the technique has been utilized in a wide range of applications, from the detection of oxygen vacancies [4] to the imaging of biological specimens [5]. Nevertheless, the practical limit of EP is still not well-understood because it is impossible study the influence of all possible experimental conditions and reconstruction parameters. Previous works [3,6] have attempted to search for the optimal experimental parameters (e.g., scan step size and probe aberrations) for low-dose ptychography by leveraging Bayesian optimization with Gaussian Processes (BO-GP) – a flexible black-box optimization framework that can automatically “explore” and “exploit” a parameter space with minimal assumptions about the data or sample. However, for more complex problems, BO-GP generally becomes less effective with increasing dimensionality and requires substantial computing resources for reconstructions.
